abstract: United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit upholds Clinton administration rule that prevented the building of roads in national forests or other public lands designated as wilderness; ruling, which found lower court had erred in finding for Wyoming, plaintiff in case, argues that Forest Service has broad jurisdiction in setting the balance of uses on the lands that it manages.
snippet: The State of Wyoming was dealt a setback after a federal appeals court ruled that the Forest Service has broad jurisdiction in setting the balance of uses on the lands that it manages.
lead_paragraph: The State of Wyoming was dealt a setback after a federal appeals court ruled that the Forest Service has broad jurisdiction in setting the balance of uses on the lands that it manages.

headline.main: Ruling Backs Forest Service in Limiting Roads in the Wild
headline.print_headline: Ruling Backs Forest Service In Limiting Roads in the Wild
headline.seo: Wyoming Dealt a Setback Over Roads on Public Lands
